text: Hey dudes, what silent hill game would you suggest someone start with who never played any?   Just go in order or start with Silent hill 2 ? Thanks!
author: xSayPleasex

text:
1. I love horror games when they're done cleverly and not just cheap jump-scare fests.
2. My favorite series is probably Silent Hill, though there have been plenty of stand-alone games I've enjoyed.
3. Silent Hill 2 all the way. Of course, I still love the other ones I've seen so far, AKA the first three.
4. Twin Victim. At least Pyramid Head's slower than I am, and usually only goes after people who have committed sins, usually of a sexual nature. Being an asexual, I shouldn't have to worry too much about that.

text:
1. I do enjoy horror games if they have a good atmosphere and don't rely too much on monster slaying.

2. The Silent Hill Series is my fovourite as well, Project Zero (Fatal Frame) and Resident Evil also have strong entries in their series.

3. A lot of the time I can not decide on a favourite between Silent Hill 2 and 3. James is an interesting character but I could not relate to him as well as to Heather.

4. The Twin Victim is definitely the thing I wouln't want to encounter alone in an alleyway. It is so digusting to me in every way, I feel uneasy when I think about it.

author: NukeA6

text:
1. Nope. I'm a big wimp so I can barely even watch some. However, I'm often intrigued by the atmosphere and design of horror games, and my brother is a big fan of them. So I still spent part of my childhood watching him play these games.

2. This is purely from a viewing standpoint, but from the ones I know something about, Silent Hill or Shivers. Silent Hill is easily one of the best horror games I've seen, and to this date it still seems to stand out among the hundreds and hundreds of horror games. The atmosphere is fantastic, the designs frightening, the music great. It really feels like this town could exist somewhere out there. It's also one of the few horror games where the main feeling I get out of it (aside from fear) is sadness and grief.
Whenever I need to look up inspiration for psychological horror (art wise) this is the go-to franchise.

Shivers is purely for nostalgic reasons. This is THE horror game I watched my family play as a child. Most experienced horror players would probably consider it silly (especially the ixupi) but god damn it it still scares me. It's also interesting to compare it to modern games, considering how it's scenery, music and gameplay is very different form many modern games. 

I wish more horror games dared to go outside the norms and even be a little cheesy. Instead of competing for being the scariest, they should try different genres and scenarios and let the horror aspects come naturally.
author: CinnamonThief

author: AdlerSchwadron

text:
There never was a "Team Silent". Key members of the team changed between every game from the first to the fourth, too. Only Akira Yamaoka and Masahiro Ito (who didn't work on 4) link these games together in any meaningful way.
The directors, producers, all changed between each game. The director for 2 was a motion cutscene/ backgrounds designer in 1, and the director for 3 was credited with "character motion" in 2, too. The guy who wrote the plot for 2 and 3 was just an enemy/ event programmer on 1 too. The director and scenario writer for 4 was also the drama director in 2.
"Team Silent" doesn't exist, in the way that each game was made with different visions from different people each time. There is overlap between each games, but most of the key roles were handled by different people.

text:
1: I love Horror games...in theory. I'm however way too easily frightened to play them by myself. XD Before, I used to play them with friends (who found great entertainment in watching me get scared), but that's become difficult lately, so now I don't play any horror games.

3: Silent Hill 2. First one I played, and I fell in love with it immediately. 
4: Pyramid Head. Just seeing him would have been terrifying. He wouldn't even need to do anything, I'd just die of fright.

author: XmasterlinkxX

text:
1.) Not the biggest on them but I think it's that I can't stand screamers in anything and it seems like every game or movie or anything scary I try just seems to rely heavily on jumps and screams and scare chords. But there are a few that stand out to me. Plus my favorite kind of horror can only be found in non-horror games, because what really freaks me out is when you're playing something simple and cheery like say Kirby! And then the game decides to throw some terrifying monstrosity your way, and then act like it was normal and nothing out of the ordinary ever happened.
2.) By what I'm familiar with I guess it'd have to be Silent Hill.
3.) 2 or 3, it's very hard to say for me as between the two if one is missing something I want the other has it and so it's a battle back and forth.
4.) Pyramid Head, super duper slow. Although that said, Twin Victim doesn't do anything to you if you just leave it be...so I can at least turn around and go to another alley without worry of it following me endlessly.

author: BygPhattyPlus

text:
1.-I enjoy horror games!
2.- SILENT HILL OBVIOUSLY I freaking love everything of this so much that I would like to be engulfed by the town to be just there... with my melancholy... that's the feeling that this games evoke on me!
3.- My favorite Silent Hill by far is the second one... with James Sunderland... omg that game blew me away, and the music is just too powerful...
4.- Twin Victim is way more scary... but Pyramid Head is the best one in the entire series, although I don't like his appearence in other games, because it was James Sunderland's monster, not other protagonists... Silent Hill is supposed to materialize all your fears, feelings, guilts, etc. Into monsters that haunts you, so Pyramid Heads in other games have no sense at all.
Thanks for this upload, I love silent hill to death!
author: El Rincón de FinoRaptor

text: Bueno....
author: 6 A l l a h 6 P h o n k 6

text:
While it's an unpopular opinion, my favorite Silent Hill is by far Silent Hill 3. I've beaten it like 8 times on the PC. I love the insanely detailed graphics, creepy sound design (its hospital is way scarier than SH2's I have to say), the story (I'm not a fan of SH2's story to be honest), the protagonist being a teen rather than an adult, and a female rather than a male, for a change, and the personality the protag has. Examining things in the game and reading Heather's thoughts on them was awesome, so much so that it disappointed me how much the other SH games didn't have nearly as much flavor text (except Homecoming, which I also like). 

SH3 was also the first Silent Hill I played, and I do wonder if that plays a role in my fondness for the game, but I don't think it overshadows the fact that I just straight up liked it a lot.
author: Daytime Sky

text: +Daytime Sky It's not really an unpopular opinion. SH 1-3 were all great games. It's what came after that (mostly) sucked.

author: daneofurexistence

text:
1. Personally, I'm not a huge fan of playing horror games. While I enjoy watching along while my friends play them, I don't really like playing them myself usually. (Unless you want to count Bioshock, which I guess isn't technically horror, but borrows many elements from the genre. I really liked that.)
2. My favorite horror franchise is probably Resident Evil, only because I have some great memories of playing RE5 on co-op with friends. (Again, unless you count Bioshock.)
3. I enjoyed watching a friend play the P.T. demo, but I guess if that's off the table, then probably Silent Hill 2 would have to be my favorite.
4. Definitely the Twin Victim. No question.
